Award.AwardTitle: Controlling the Mechanical Properties of Fiber Bundles through their Molecular Architecture

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
In nature, bundles of biological fibers are a common solution for many mechanical tasks. Because they exhibit unusual mechanical properties and a stunning adaptability to changing requirements, they are also of interest to the field of nanotechnology.
One example of a fiber bundle in biology are microtubules which are essential for a variety of cell functions. They are tubular protein filaments which consist of parallel filaments whose interactions determine the mechanics of the overall microtubule. In nature, the exact architecture of microtubules is tightly controlled for each cell type.

Some of the most drastic mechanical consequences of the fiber architecture are expected to predominantly affect very short microtubules. These predictions have however been difficult to verify because the short length regime is barely accessible to measurements with conventional techniques. In the proposed research, we will employ a high speed, high resolution position detection system based on the scattering of laser light which will allow for measurements in the previously inaccessible microtubule length regime. The thermal fluctuations of microtubules will be exploited to extract their mechanical properties. In addition, the project will study the connection between the number of constituent filaments and the emergent mechanical properties. Results will be compared to state-of-the-art polymer models.

The proposed research aims to identify and quantify the interplay between microtubule molecular architecture and mechanics. The results will not only allow for a deeper understanding of how cellular functions are implemented on a molecular scale, but will also yield insights into nanotechnology because they can be generalized to other fiber bundles, including artificial ones. The gained knowledge may lead to new artificially designed materials available to consumers.

The research will expose students to a rich interplay between scientific fields as diverse as theoretical physics, biochemistry, molecular biology, engineering and material science, thereby training them in developing an interdisciplinary approach towards research.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Bundles of biological fibers are found widely in nature. They facilitate a multitude of biological functions and exhibit surprising mechanical properties. An important example of fiber bundles in biology are microtubules, which are essential for a variety of cell functions. Several studies have provided evidence that their specific molecular architecture causes microtubule bending stiffness to depend strongly on filament length, in stark contrast to common fiber material for which the bending stiffness is expected to be independent of its length. To explain this length dependence, the wormlike-bundle model has been developed by our collaborators. It provides a link between the macroscopic mechanical properties, the bending stiffness, and the molecular architecture. It makes specific predictions concerning which elements of the molecular structures cause a certain macroscopic response. This model is very powerful, because changes in the macroscopically measured bending stiffness can be linked to the site of molecular action. We provided experimental evidence that minute changes in the architecture lead indeed to drastic changes in the bending stiffness of microtubules and were able to localize the site of action.  Our results provide an unexpected new insight into microtubule assembly and dynamics.

 

Our earlier work demonstrated also that microtubules do not follow the rules of simple polymer dynamics but studying the dynamics in detail remained difficult due to the lack of a suitable assay for high-bandwidth and resolution measurements.

We developed an assay compatible with both requirements and demonstrated that filament fluctuations can be indeed measured with sufficient precision within the relevant frequency range. This opens a new window for the investigation of fiber bundle dynamics and will allow us to test current models for fiber and fiber bundle dynamics.

 

Six graduate and two undergraduate students were trained in an interdisciplinary environment that included experimental and theoretical physics, biomedical engineering, biology and chemistry. Two graduate students continued their career as postdoctoral researchers at prominent research institutes and pursue an academic career. One became researcher in local biotech company; another became researcher and senior design engineer in the chip manufacturer industry. The third one became seismic imager and geophysicist in the oil and gas exploration industry.  Both undergraduate researchers plan to pursue a career in science.

 

New international collaborations with leading researchers in the field of semiflexible polymer dynamics were established.
